newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU threat to World Cup soccer in Paris stadium row.
newsitem.headline: EU threat to World Cup soccer in Paris stadium row.

text.p: The European Commission dealt a blow to France's efforts to host the 1998 soccer World Cup finals on Wednesday, stepping up legal moves against the way Paris awarded contracts to build and run its new stadium.

"The European Commission has decided to send a reasoned opinion to France for its incorrect application of EU public works rules related to the construction of the 'Stade de France' at Saint Denis in the Paris suburbs," it said in a statement.
"Reasoned opinions" are the last stage before a disputed case goes to the European Court of Justice.

"Concerns raised by the Commission relate to the award of the contract and concessions and the non-respect of the principle of equal treatment, because the offer was changed during the course of proceedings," it added.
"In the absence of a satisfactory response within two months of receiving this reasoned opinion, the Commission could take action before the Court of Justice," the statement said.
The challenge could delay work on the 80,000-seater "Grand Stade de France" stadium being built in northern Paris as the centrepiece of French plans for the finals.

Commission inquiries stem from October 1995, after competing contractors cried foul over the allocation of contracts, accusing successful bidders Bouyges, Dumez and SGE of having changed their bid after its submission.
Other issues include concern about the granting of stadium operating concessions without a tendering procedure.
The 2.67-billion-franc ($487 million) stadium is due for completion in November this year. ($=5.48 francs)
